simple fact
may appear my fate had been Chemist

ral philosophy has is the genius that has
regulated my fate I
wish
desire
the ir refore
in this account
of my early years to state those facts which
led to my
love pursuit
first aqu
of that study.
predeliction for that science. When
I was eleven years old we all went on a party
of pleasure to
Thonon Thonon.
and were confined there
b obil obliged by the rain and
t T he inclemen
cy of the weather obliged us to remain a day
confined to the inn. In this house I chanced
to fin ed d
a fo volume
s of the Works of Corne
lius Agrippa.
And I opened it with apathy
but
^
the theory that he attempted to d
demonstrate and the wonderful facts that
he relates chan soon changed this feeling into
continued to re with
enthusiasm. A new
light dawned upon my mind and I com
bounding with joy I communicated my
discovery to my father. I cannot help here remark
ing
the many opportunities
parents
^
instructors
have
posess
of directing the attention of their pupils to
useful knowledge, which they utterly neglect.
My father looked carelessly at the tit t le page
of my book â€” Ah
and said Ah! Cornelius
Agrippa! â€” My dear Victor do not waste
your time upon this â€“ it is sad trash.
If instead of this remark or rather excla
mation my father had taken the pains to
exp ound
^
lain
to me that the principles of
Agrippa had been entirely exploded. And
aan and that
another
a modern
system of science
had been introduced which possessed much
greater power than the ancient because
the powers of the ancient were pretended
and chimerical, while those of the moderns
are real and practical; under such
circumstances I should certainly have thrown
Agrippa aside, and with my imagination
warmed as it was w sh ould probably have
aplied myself to m
the more
ra rational
theory of chemistry which
has at present
has resulted from modern discoveries
the approbation of the learned.
It is even possible that the train of my ideas might never have recieved
that fatal impulse which led me to my ruin.
But the
cursory glance my father had taken of
my volume by no means assured me
that he was acquainted with
the
^
its
contents;
and I continued to read with the greatest
avidity.
[When I returned home, my first
care was to procure
this
^
the
^
whole
works of this
author and afterwards those of Paracel
sus and Albertus Magnus. I read and studied
the wild fancies of the se authors with
delight, they appeared to me treasures
known to few besides myself; and, although
I often wished to
discover
communicate
these secret stores
of knowledge
from to my father yet his in
definite censure of my favorite Agrippa,
always withheld me.
I let I disclosed my secret
to Elizabeth therefore, under a strict promise
of secrecy; but she did not interest herself
in
them
the subject,
and I was left by her to pursue
my studies alone. â€“
It may appear very strange that a
desci
ple
of Albertus Magnus should arise in the
eighteenth century, but our family was not
scientifical, and I
did
had
not attend ed
any of the
lectures given at Geneva. My dreams were
therefore undisturbed by reality, and I entered
with the greates diligence into the search
of the philosophers stone and the
or if you chose petrum philosophale
elizer vi
elixer of life
tÃ¦ . But the latter obtained my most
undi
ved attention; wealth was an inferior
object but what would be the glory
of the discovery if I could besto forever
banish disease from the human frame
and render man
unatainable by
invunerable to any
b
ut a violent death.
Nor were these my only visions, the
raising of ghosts or devils
^
was also a favour
was a promise liberally accorded by
ite pursuit and If I never saw any
my favourite authors; the fulfilment of which I most eagerly sought;
& if my incantations were always unsuccessful
attributed
it
the failure
rather to my own inexperience
th and mistake, than
^
to a
want of skill
^
or fidelity
in
my instructor s .
When I was about fifteen my f

fermentation of liquors â€“ di stillation
of which

excited my astonishment, but my utmost

engaged by some experiements
air pump
electrical machine

employed
used

The ignorance of my philosopher es s

thier
credit with

any

cocc

w W hen I was about
twelve fourteen
years
old we were at our house near
Belrive when we witnessed the a
violent
at
and
terrible thunder storm
it advanced from behind Jura and
the and the thunder was heard at
once from the d
several quarte rs
of the heavens and burst
at once with and
frightful loudness.
^
from various quarters of the heavens
I witnessed th is e
elemental storm with pleasure
and remain ed while
it
the storm
lasted at
watching its
its progress
with curiosity
& delight
the door watchin g . When it was most
As I stood at the door
violent , on a sudden I beheld
the
^
a stream of
fire issue
from an old be and beautiful
oak about wh twenty yards from
our house and
when
so soon as
the dazz
dazzling light
had dissa dissappeared
the
pa vanished, the oak
hand
had dissappeared
an
& nothing remained but a
rent
^
blasted
stump. remained . When we
visited it the next morning we found
the trea tree shattered in a
singular manner. It was not splin
tered by the shock, but entirely
reduced to thin ribands of wood. The
C I never saw any thing so utterly
destroyed. The catastrophe of the
tree excited my extreme
astonish
ment
and
caused
^
induced
me to aply wi ith
fresh di ligence to the study of
chemistry natural philosophy which promised an ex
clamatio planation of th e i se sort of
phÃ¦nonema. On Elizabeth and
Clerval it produced a di very different
effect. They admired the beauty
of the storm without wishing to
analyze its causes. Henry said that
the Fairies and giants were at
war and Elizabeth attempted
a picture of it.
As I grew older my attempts
in science were of a higher nature.
I endeavou produced little earthquakes
and tried every kind of combination
of gasses to and elements to ascertain
the results.
An d
^
Among other questions suggested by natural objects
I
as eagerly enquired of my father
what
^
the nature & the origin of
thunder and lightening. was.
He
replied, electricity; describing at the same
time the effect of that power. He
made
constructed
a small electrical machine and exhi
bited a few experiments and made a
kite with a wire & string
and
which
drew down
that fluid from the clouds.
This last
blow st stroke compleated
the overthrow of Cornelius Agrippa, Albertus
Magnus and Paracelsus, who had so long
reigned the lords of my imagination. But
by some fatality I did not feel enclined to
commence any modern system and this
inclination
disinclination
was influenced by the following
circumstance.
My father expressed a wish that I
should attend a course of lectures upon
natural philosophy, to which I
^
cheerfully
consented and
one evening that I spent in town at the
house of Clerval's father I heard that
Mr â€” was lef at met M. O P a proficient
in Chemistry who left the company at
an early hour to h give his lecture upon
tha n t
science enquiring as he went out
if any one would him I went but
Some accident prevented my attending the series of these lectures
this lecture was unfortunately nearly the
until
they were nearly over they it was nearly finihsed. The
last
lecture which I attended being thus the almost the last in his
in his course
^
was entirely incomprehensible to me.
â€“ the professor talked
with the greatest fluency of potassium &
Boron zinc bismuth â€“ of sulphats and oxids
and displayed so many
words
terms
to which
I could not
affix
any
no
idea: that
I was
disgusted with
the appearance of a science
that appeared to me to contain only words.
From this time untill I went to
Colledge I entirely neglected my formerly
adored study of
chemistry
the science of
natural philosophy
although I still
read with delight Pliny and Buffons
authors
that stood about on a par
ar of
in my estimation of nearly equal interest & utility.
My
studies
occupations
at this age were
th principally the
mathematics, which I delighted in an and most
of the branches of study appertaining th to that
science. I was also busily employed in learning
languages Latin was
^
already
familiar to me and I began to
read without the help of the
dictionary lexicon some of the
easiest greek authors. â€“I
also
understood English&
german perfectly: th
ese is are
is
list of my accom
plishments at
that time
th e period the age of
and you may
conceive that my hours were fully employd
in acquiring and maintaining a knowledge
of this various literature.
As I before mentioned my brothers
were much younger than myself.
Ernest the second of our family was five
Another task
soon
^
also
devolved upon
me when I became the instructor
of my brothers. Ernest was five years
younger than myself, and was my
principal pupil. He had been aflicted
with ill health from his infancy
&
thro which
Elizabeth and I had been his constant
m nurses I
his disposition was gentle but
he was incapable any severe appli
cation. William the younge er st
of our
family was quite a child and the
most beautiful little fellow in the
world, his lively blue eyes dimpled cheeks
and affectionate
endearing manners
inspired the tenderest affection. Such
was our domestic circle from which
care and pain seemed for ever banish
ed.
f My father directed our studies
and my mother partook of our
enjoyments.
we were all equal
we none
neither
of
us possessed
an envied
preheminence
over the other
the
voice of command was never heard
among us but mutual affection
engaged us all to comply with
, &
to
obey the slightest desire of each
other.
